slides.title: Introduction to Child Care
slides.content:
**Daily Care of Young Children**

Good child care practices ensure:
- Healthy growth
- Prevention of infections
- Safety from accidents
- Emotional security
- Proper development

**Key Areas:**
- Hygiene and cleanliness
- Safe environment
- Play and learning
- Sleep and rest

**Your Role:** Educate mothers and demonstrate good practices at Anganwadi.

slides.title: Personal Hygiene for Children
slides.content:
**Daily Hygiene Routines**

**Bathing:**
- Daily bath with lukewarm water
- Clean all body parts gently
- Dry properly, especially skin folds
- Use mild soap

**Hand Washing:**
- Critical times: Before eating, after toilet
- Teach proper technique (both sides, between fingers)
- Use soap and clean water
- Make it a habit from early age

**Oral Care:**
- Clean gums with soft cloth (infants)
- Start brushing when teeth appear
- Twice daily brushing
- Avoid giving sweets

**Nail Cutting:**
- Keep nails short and clean
- Cut regularly
- Prevents dirt accumulation
- Reduces infection risk

**Hair Care:**
- Regular washing
- Comb daily
- Check for lice
- Keep hair tied (girls)

slides.title: Diaper and Toilet Training
slides.content:
**Diaper Care (0-2 years)**

**If Using Diapers:**
- Change frequently (every 3-4 hours)
- Clean bottom with water
- Dry before wearing new diaper
- Use diaper rash cream if needed
- Air time for bottom (prevents rash)

**Cloth Nappies:**
- Wash thoroughly with soap
- Dry in sunlight
- Soft, clean cloth only

**Toilet Training (18-24 months)**

**When to Start:**
- Child shows readiness signs
- Stays dry for longer periods
- Shows interest

**How to Train:**
- Introduce potty chair
- Make it routine (after meals, waking up)
- Be patient, don't scold
- Praise success
- Accidents are normal

**Important:** Every child learns at own pace. Don't force or compare.

slides.title: Safe Sleep Practices
slides.content:
**Ensuring Safe Sleep**

**Sleep Duration:**
- Newborn: 16-18 hours/day
- 6 months: 14-15 hours/day
- 1 year: 12-14 hours/day
- 2-3 years: 11-13 hours/day
- 3-6 years: 10-12 hours/day

**Safe Sleep for Infants:**
- Always on BACK (not stomach or side)
- Firm, flat surface
- No pillows, soft toys in crib
- Don't overheat baby
- Room-sharing (not bed-sharing recommended)

**Reducing SIDS Risk:**
- Back to sleep position
- Breastfeeding
- No smoking around baby
- Pacifier during sleep (optional)

**Good Sleep Habits:**
- Fixed bedtime routine
- Dark, quiet room
- Comfortable temperature
- No screen time before bed

slides.title: Child Safety at Home
slides.content:
**Preventing Home Accidents**

**Falls:**
- No baby walkers (dangerous!)
- Gates on stairs
- Window guards
- Supervision on beds/sofas

**Burns and Scalds:**
- Keep hot liquids away
- Turn pot handles inward
- Cover electrical sockets
- Keep matches/lighters away

**Poisoning:**
- Keep medicines locked
- Store cleaning products high up
- No storage in food containers
- Rat poison in safe place

**Choking:**
- No small objects for children <3 years
- Cut food into small pieces
- Supervise during eating
- No nuts, hard candies for toddlers

**Drowning:**
- Never leave alone near water
- Empty buckets after use
- Supervise bath time

**Action:** Teach mothers to childproof homes!

slides.title: Play and Learning
slides.content:
**Importance of Play**

**Play is NOT just fun - it's how children LEARN!**

**Benefits of Play:**
- Physical development (gross & fine motor skills)
- Mental development (problem-solving, creativity)
- Social skills (sharing, cooperation)
- Emotional development (expressing feelings)
- Language development

**Age-Appropriate Play:**

**0-6 Months:**
- Colorful toys to look at
- Rattles to shake
- Tummy time

**6-12 Months:**
- Stacking toys
- Balls to roll
- Simple books

**1-3 Years:**
- Building blocks
- Drawing with crayons
- Pretend play (kitchen set)
- Outdoor play (running, climbing)

**3-6 Years:**
- Puzzles
- Art and craft
- Group games
- Storytelling

**No expensive toys needed! Simple household items work great.**

slides.title: Clothing and Comfort
slides.content:
**Dressing Children Appropriately**

**General Principles:**
- Comfortable, not tight
- Soft, breathable fabric (cotton)
- Easy to put on and remove
- Weather-appropriate

**For Infants:**
- One layer more than adults
- Loose clothing
- Soft fabric
- No strings (choking hazard)
- Check if too hot/cold (feel neck/back)

**For Toddlers:**
- Easy for toilet training
- Safe for active play
- No dangling strings
- Non-slip footwear

**Weather Care:**

**Summer:**
- Light colored, loose clothes
- Cotton fabric
- Head cover in sun
- Keep hydrated

**Winter:**
- Layer clothing
- Warm but not overheated
- Cover head and feet
- Remove extra layers indoors

**Rainy Season:**
- Dry clothes immediately after rain
- Extra care against infections

slides.title: Responsive Caregiving
slides.content:
**Understanding and Responding to Child's Needs**

**What is Responsive Caregiving?**
- Noticing child's signals
- Understanding what child needs
- Responding appropriately and promptly
- Building secure attachment

**Infant Crying - What it Means:**
- Hungry
- Wet/dirty diaper
- Tired
- Too hot/cold
- Wants attention/comfort
- Unwell

**How to Respond:**
- Pick up and comfort
- Check for basic needs
- Talk/sing softly
- Gentle rocking
- Breastfeed if hungry

**Building Bonding:**
- Eye contact while feeding
- Talking to baby
- Skin-to-skin contact
- Responding to smiles
- Physical affection (hugs, kisses)

**Remember:** Responding to crying does NOT spoil a baby. It builds trust and security.

slides.title: Screen Time Guidelines
slides.content:
**Managing Screen Exposure**

**WHO/AAP Recommendations:**

**Under 2 Years:**
- NO screen time (except video calls with family)
- Critical brain development period
- Need real interactions, not screens

**2-5 Years:**
- Maximum 1 hour per day
- High-quality educational content only
- Co-view with parents

**Why Limit Screens?**

**Negative Effects:**
- Delays language development
- Reduces physical activity
- Affects sleep
- Reduces parent-child interaction
- May cause behavioral problems
- Eye strain

**Better Alternatives:**
- Reading books together
- Outdoor play
- Singing songs
- Creative activities
- Family time

**If Using Screens:**
- Educational content
- Parent involvement
- Take frequent breaks
- No screens during meals
- No screens before bedtime

question.questionText: What is the safest sleep position for infants to prevent SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome)?
question.explanation: Infants should ALWAYS sleep on their BACK to reduce the risk of SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome). This is the safest sleep position. Never place infants on their stomach or side to sleep.
